Comments_List: General introduction to implicature, presupposition, experimental pragmatics, speech acts, etc. from a  BOSS
thorough understanding of pragmatic theory including Gricean and neo-Gricean pragmatics, presentation-making skills, and much more
Approach could be a bit more dialogic, especially in the more philosophy-inflected parts of the class
This course is a rare gem. Professor Horn is a giant in the field, and he makes the material accessible and lively in his lectures. Every single lecture was insightful and thorough.
Take it from a man who has literally changed the field.

Speech act stuff is great, presuppositions and all (mid-way through the semester) get a bit more technical -- but if you're interested in learning about pragmatics, Prof. Horn is certainly the person to do it with!

This course is a rare gem. If you have ever wondered about how context gives language meaning, please take this course. The course explores how this phenomenon happens with a rigor that Professor Horn generously provides. 

Take a look at the syllabus and see if a couple of the readings stand out. If some do, it is pretty much guaranteed you will enjoy most of the other readings you might not have heard of before. The workload is also entirely reasonableweekly readings, 3 p-sets, one low-key presentation and a final paper.
